text: [Music]
There's an old saying, just because you
can't see something doesn't mean it's
not
there. Um, my work
is it's a reflection of of myself. Um
what I wanted to do is to
um show the world that the little things
can be the biggest
things. Um we we all seem to think that
you know if we uh if we look down on the
ground there's nothing there and we use
the word
nothing. Um nothing doesn't exist
because there's always something. My
mother told me that um when I was a
child that I should always respect the
little
things. Um what made me do this work? I
I shall go into my my story.
Uh it's it's quite a little story but I
shall go into it. Um this all started
when I was age five. Um what made me do
it at school? I will admit this
academically I couldn't express myself.
So I was more or less classed as
nothing. So my world was seen as
less. So um I decided I didn't really
want to be a part of that world. So I
thought I need to
retreat into something else. So when my
mother used to take me to
school, she thought I was at school and
I used to uh do a Uturn when her back
was turned and run off and hide in the
shed at the back of the
garden. Now um the one time I I was in
the shed
and my mother suspected something
thinking I was at school. And my mother
was like the woman in Tom and
Jerry. So So you just see her feet.
So I was hiding in the shed like that
and all of a
sudden and then I saw her legs and then
she said grabbed me like that cuz my
mother's quite big and she lifted me up
and she
says how come you're not at school and I
told her I couldn't face it because the
way I that the teacher was treating me,
ridiculing me, and using me as an
example of failure. So, I I I told her,
but at that age, I obviously I couldn't
really express it that way, but I told
her I didn't feel right. And and then
she just said, "You're going back to
school tomorrow." and walked off. And I
didn't expect that because I expected
one of
these, but I didn't get it. So, I'm
sitting there
thinking, and then as I looked down on
the ground, I noticed there were some
ants running
around. And I went into this little
fantasy world. And I thought, these
ants, are they looking for the queen ant
or did I need somewhere to live? So, I
thought perhaps if I make these ants
some
apartments, they'll move in.
So I
did and how I set about that. I got some
splinters of wood and I sliced these
little splinters of wood with a broken
shard of glass. Constructed this little
apartment. Well, it looked like a little
shanty shed when I finished, but I
thought perhaps the ant won't know.
He'll probably move in. And so I did.
That was a bit crude at the time. And I
made all these little apartments and
little merrygorounds, seesaws and
swings, little ladders. And then I
encouraged the ants to come around by
putting sugar and things like that. And
then I sat down and all the ants came
along. And all I could hear was, "Is
this for
us?" And I says, "Yes, they're all for
you." And they moved in and decided not
to pay me any rent.
I'll get to the serious bit. And from
there that, you know, I was watching
this this little world and and you know,
it it became a part of me.
Um when I discovered that I had this
gift, I wanted to experiment with this
world that we can't see because ants are
very intelligent.
So I I realized that there was more to
life than just everything that we see
around us. That's that's huge. So I
started to educate myself on this
molecular
level. And as I as I got older, I I I
continued. I showed my mother. My mother
told me to take it smaller. Now, um I
shall show you something here and I'll
explain. As you can
see, that's a pin
[Applause]
head. Now, that is called the Huff
House. The gentleman who commissioned me
to do this was a gentleman called Peter
Huff. And he says to me, "Willard, can
you put my house on a pin
head?" So I says, "How are you going to
fit in
there?" And then he said to
me, "I don't believe you can do it. Can
you really do it?" And I says,
"Well, try me." And then he said, "Um,
but I I I don't believe that you can do
this." So I said, "Okay." So I cut a
long story short, I went home, went
underneath the microscope, and I crushed
up a piece of glass, crushed it up, and
underneath underneath the microscope,
there were splinters of glass. Some of
them were quite
jagged. So I was crushing up these
pieces of glass, which as you can see,
that is the actual that's the actual
frame of the house.
And
um the actual roof is made up of uh a
fiber which I found in my sister's old
teddy
bear. So I I got the teddy bear and I
said, "Do you mind if I pull out one of
your fibers?" So I did and I looked it
underneath the microscope and it was
some of it it was flat. So that that I
decided to slice these up with the tool
that I make by I sharpen the the end of
a needle into a blade and then I I
actually slow down my whole nervous
system and then I work between my
heartbeat and I have one and a half
seconds to actually
move and at the same time I have to
watch I don't inhale my own work at the
same time.
[Applause]
because that has happened to
me. So what I did, like I said, come
back to the glass. I I found these
little bits of glass and and I had to
make them square. So I'm thinking, how
can I do this? So what I did, I got a
oil stone, broke the edge of a oil stone
off, and what I did, I took pieces of
glass and I started to rub them. I used
a little tweezer, which I made from an
air clip, and I put built up rubber
around the end of the tweezer so it
wouldn't crush the glass. And then I
started rubbing very, very
gently till some of the edges were quite
square. And then I constructed it. And
how I constructed it is by making
grooves in the top of the pin head and
then pushing the glass in with its own
friction. And as I was doing it, what
happened the the instrument that I used
turned into a catapult and it went like
this and then that was
it.
Gone. So I'm thinking Mr. huff isn't
going to be very happy when I told him
his house has gone to another into the
atmosphere
somewhere. So, cut the story short, I
decided that I had to go back and do it.
So, I found some more and I decided to
sort of construct it very very slowly,
holding my breath, working between my
heartbeat, and making sure everything's
level cuz because it's such a a small
sculpture. Yeah. Nothing can can go
wrong. And I I decided to build it up.
Then I used fibers out of my jumper
which I held and stretched and made the
beams going around the house and the
actual windows and the balcony had to be
sort of constructed. I use money spiders
web to actually attach certain things
which sent me
insane but I managed to do it and um
when I finished it I came back the next
day and noticed the house was occupied.
Have we ever heard of a dustmite?
Darren Dustmite and his family moved
in. So, um, basically I' I'd completed
the house and there you are.
[Applause]
[Music]
Right. As you can see, um, Bart Simpson
is having a little
argument. I think they're arguing about
the space on the
pin. There's not enough room for the two
of them. So, I didn't think he was going
to throw a bard off. I think he was just
warning him, actually. But, um, this one
was made out of a nylon tag out of my
shirt. What I did, I I plugged the tag
out and, uh, put it underneath the
microscope. I used a needle which has
got a slight blade on the end. Can
anybody see the blade on the end of that
needle? So, um what I did is the same
process where I just kind of hold my
breath and just work away very very
slowly manipulating the plastic cutting
it because it behaves different whenever
you work on that level. Things behave
different because it's on this molecular
level. things change and they act
different and sometimes they turn into
little catapults and things go up in the
air and you know that all different
things happen but I had to make a little
barrier going around it out of
cellophane to stop stop it moving then
static electricity set in and it
went and I'm trying to remove it and the
static interfering with everything so
you know the sweat dripping off my head
because I have to carve Simpson like
that in that position and after I've cut
out the shape, then I have to make sure
that there's room for Bart's
neck. So, after I've done the same
thing, then I have to paint it. And
after I've actually sculpted them, um, I
have to paint them. I experimented with
a uh I found a dead fly and I plucked
the hair off the fly's head. Decided to
make a
[Music]
paintbrush, but I would never do it to a
living
[Laughter]
fly
because I've I've heard a fly in pain
and they go
even though they get on our nerves. I
would never kill an insect because, you
know, all creatures, great and small.
You know, there there's a hymn that says
that. So, um, what I decided to do is to
pluck fine hair out of my
face. And I looked at it underneath the
microscope. That was the paintbrush. And
whilst I'm painting, I have to be very
careful because the paint starts to to
turn into little blobs. and it starts to
dry very quickly. So, I have to be very
quick. Um, if I'm not, it'll end up
looking not like what it's supposed to
look like. It could end up looking like
Humpty
Dumpty or somebody else. So, I have to
be very very careful. So, um, this one
took me approximately I would say 6 to 7
weeks. um my work rough estimates
sometimes five six to seven weeks you
can't always anticipate it's very
painstaking work but um the best things
come in small
[Applause]
[Music]
packages as you can see that's Charlton
H brought down to size
He says to me, "Willard, as you can see
him
saying, why me?" I says, "I enjoyed your
film, that's why." As you can see, there
there's an aphid fly there. That's just
to show the scale and the actual size of
the sculpture. I would say it probably
measures quarter of a millimeter. In
America they say a period stop. So I
would say if you cut a a period stop in
half or full stop that's about the size
of the the whole thing.
Um it's made the chariot's made of gold
and Charlton H is made of a floating
fiber which I took out the air. When the
sunlight comes through the window you
see these little fibers. And what I
normally do is walk around a
room trying to find one and then I put
it underneath the microscope. I remember
one time I was doing it and the window
was open and there's a lady standing by
the bus stop and she saw me walking
around like this.
Then she looked at me and then I
went and then she went, "Oh, okay. He's
not mad." Um, yeah. To actually do this
thing, the actual chariot is made of
gold. I I had a 24 karat gold ring and I
cut off a little flake of gold and and
then I cut it bent it round and made it
into the chariot. And the horse is made
from nylon and the spider's web is for
the for the resins on the horse. To get
the symmetrical shape of the horse was
very difficult because it had I had to
get the horse to rare up and look as
though it was sort of in some kind of
action. When I did this one, a gentleman
seen it and said to me, "There's no way
you can do this. You must have used some
kind of machine. There's no way a man
can do that. It must be a machine." So I
said, "Okay, then if you say it's a
machine,
[Music]
That one took me
approximately 6
[Applause]
[Music]
weeks. The most famous statue in the
world.
This one I would say was a a serious
challenge
[Laughter]
because I had to put the torch on the
top. That one is more or less the same
type of process. The bottom of it is
carved from a grain of
sand because I wanted to get a bit of a
stone effect. I used a microscopic shard
of diamond to actually carve the actual
base. Well, I can look at this one and I
can be very proud of this because that
that statue was always sort of kept an
image in my head of, you know, the
beginning of people coming to America.
So it's sort of Ellie silent and and
seeing America for the first time and
and that's the first thing they saw. So
I wanted to add that little image and
and and and this is
it and we all know that is the Hulk. I
wanted to create movement in the eye of
a needle because as we know we see
needles but people are not familiar with
the eye of a needle but apart from
putting a thread through it. So I broke
the needle
and made the needle look like the hulk's
broken it. It's
um I had to make little holes in in in
the base of needle to shove his feet in.
So most of my work I don't use glue.
They're going with their own friction
and that's that's how I managed to do
it. So it was a sort of a as you can see
he's looking at the moment he's got
little grimace on his face and his mouth
must be probably about three
microns. So the eyes are probably about
one micron or
something. That chip
there that's made from 24 karat gold.
And I normally rig it with the web of a
money spider, but I had to rig it with
strands of glue because the web of the
spider, it was sending me insane cuz I
couldn't get the web to move off. And
that's 24 karat gold. And it's
constructed, I built it, constructed
each plank of gold. And the whole thing
is sort of symmetrical. The flag had to
be made out of little strands of gold.
You know, it's it's almost like um doing
a surgical operation to get this thing
right.
[Applause]
[Music]
[Applause]
As you can see, um
dress. Um it's something I wanted to do
just to show how I could get the
symmetrical shape, the actual rigging on
the res on the horse made from the same
sort of thing. And that was uh done with
a uh particles for my shirt and the pin
head. I've made greenery on there by
scraping the particles off a green shirt
and then pressed onto the needle.
[Applause]
